p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
PARLIAMENTARY REPRESENTATION
Issue of Writ

The SPEAKER (10:01): I inform the House that, on Friday, 15 June 2018, I issued writs for the election of members to serve for the electoral divisions of Braddon, in the state of Tasmania, Fremantle, in the state of Western Australia, Longman, in the state of Queensland, Mayo, in the state of South Australia and Perth, in the state of Western Australia to fill the vacancies caused by the respective resignations of Justine Keay, Joshua Wilson, Susan Lamb, Rebekha Sharkie and Timothy Hammond. The dates in connection with the by-elections are fixed as follows: close of rolls, Friday, 22 June; date of nominations, Thursday, 5 July; date of polling, Saturday, 28 July; and return of writ on or before Sunday, 23 September 2018. I thank the House.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:02): Today I present the 24th report of the Petitions Committee for the 45th Parliament, together with 24 petitions and 25 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
PETITIONS
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:02): I present the following petitions:
Lottery

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House: Gambling operators are permitting betting on the outcome of lotteries, with these synthetic lottery operators making no contribution to State lotteries taxes.
We therefore ask the House to: Amend the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 so as to ban betting on the outcome of lotteries and thereby prohibit the operation of synthetic lotteries in Australia.
from 735 citizens (Petition No. PN0221)
Alcohol

The reason being, vulnerable, reformed alcoholics (including my brother) may relapse and have to resume therapeutic treatment. This is an unwanted burden for family and friends of the alcoholic. A relapsed alcoholic also places financial and physical demands on people of the public and private health institutions, thankyou

TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES This petition is from caring citizens of Australia who draw to the attention of the House: To remove advertising of alcohol from sports venues and reality T.V. programs eg: Front Bar, newspapers and magazines.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. PN0347)
Foreign Affairs

TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES This petition of CERTAIN CITIZENS OF AUSTRALIA draws to the attention of the House: The Citizens of Australia request that the House of Representatives of Australia retains the recognised name of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM ) as per the United Nations Agreement.

We therefore ask the House to: Respect the negotiations undertaken between Greece and FYROM and refrain from considering any action on this matter until negotiations are completed and formal agreements reached.
from 12,384 citizens (Petition No. PN0348)
Bruce Highway

TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES This petition of Concerned citizens of Wide Bay draws to the attention of the House: The Bruce Highway, as part of the national highway, is Queensland's main transport corridor, but for the past 50 years it has remained a treacherous stretch of road north of the Sunshine Coast. Not only has this created a transport bottleneck which strangles our regional economies, but in the past year there have been six fatalities, and countless other road trauma that has devastated families and communities in the Gympie region and Fraser Coast. Building Section D of the Cooroy to Curra bypass is not about convenience, it is about saving lives. Every year it is delayed comes at an unacceptable cost. Proof that Section D will save lives exists in the dramatic reduction – near elimination - of the road toll south of Gympie, where Section A, B and C of the bypass have been completed. While it is appreciated that other regional areas in Australia have roads in need of upgrade, there can be no denying the safety issues that elevate Section D to the top of the list; there should be no human argument which will ever favour easing congestion over saving lives.
We therefore ask the House to: Support the fast-track of construction of Section D of the Cooroy to Curra Bruce Highway upgrade.
from 168 citizens (Petition No. PN0349)
Tasmania Highway

To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives This Petition of: Peter Brohier Draws to the attention of the House: In 1996, the Coalition introduced a scheme capable of making Bass Strait ferries part of the National Highway. The scheme aimed at directly driving the economy of South Eastern Australia by moving increased numbers of people and vehicles interstate. It would integrate the economy of Tasmania into the national economy. This initiative closed the final gap in the National Highway making the cost of ferry travel compatible with interstate road travel. Following a promise to expand the scheme in 2001, it was quietly reversed. Without rigorous controls, this turned a highway equalisation scheme and associated promises, into a narrow subsidy, limiting passenger volumes and growth of the Tasmanian economy. So, the water barrier of Bass Strait continues, losing billions in revenue from activities that need people on both sides of the Strait. Federation was about integrating economies, not continuing a separation that justifies additional federal subsidies for Tasmania. Without new highway construction, a simple, all-year, adjustment of passenger fares would immediately extend the Hume Highway to Hobart. The democratic process, utilised by the nation with bi-partisan support, has now failed. Despite massive federal funding, Bass Strait ferries are now not required to compatibly connect the National Highway.
We therefore ask the House to: Request the exercise of a Royal Prerogative to commandeer two ferries to meet the obligations the Australian Government has to its island state.
from 1 citizen (Petition No. PN0352)
Veterans

A critical component to a veteran's (or partner) financial future is a home, particularly if a veteran is injured or killed. Financial uncertainty is a major reason for suicide in veterans. Defence Home Ownership and Assistance Scheme (DHOAS) allows a degree of certainty to a home, via a subsidy to a home loan. Importantly, if this is not accessed while still employed by Defence, the veteran/widow has 2 years to access the subsidy (which can add up to over $100K over its lifetime) before the legislation dictates an expiry. For example, a veteran can serve for over 20 years, have multiple combat tours and if discharged due to injury (or killed) has 2 years to apply for the subsidy. That limitation is morally wrong and needs to be removed. Many veterans/partners are often not in a position (medically or financially) to purchase a home within that 2 year period, particularly if separation and children are involved. Removing this 2 year period will assist in easing pressure and give a degree of certainty to access the loan subsidy at a later date. If a veteran meets the qualifying criteria they should never lose the ability to access this subsidy.

We are not seeking any change to the qualification component. We are requesting removal (or substantial increase in time) of the 2 year limitation to the DHOAS Act 2008 (Cth) and DHOAS Regulations 2008 (Cth). This should be a quick fix to an issue that impacts a number of veteran's futures.
from 362 citizens (Petition No. EN0263)
Marriage

Recently the House passed a Bill that changed the definition of Marriage to allow Same-sex couples to marry. Since this we have seen the consequences that have followed - with outrageous public behaviour, to implement safe schools teaching in the education system, attacks on religious freedom that was not even considered at the time of passing this Bill. Children's right of a mother and father. No Law or Bill should be passed through of Parliament or our Constitution that discriminates on ones human rights and excludes the rights and freedom's of others to choose, in order to push through the rights of the LGBTQ. You see the severe consequences of this in Canada which had lead to passing other un lawful laws. This is un Constitutional and un-Australian. This Bill in itself comes against our Constitutional human rights and should be challenged in the High Court and repealed, and the Marriage Act returned to it original form from over 50 years ago.

Request: Request the House to act upon this request to overturn the damage that has been carried out, and to restore the Traditional Definition of Marriage. Marriage Act 1961. Marriage is between the union of a man and a woman entered into for life. Bermuda has just recently been successful in abolishing their laws after six months from being passed. Australia can do the same, for over all good of the people and nation. Lets put it through now!!! Its never too late to do the right thing!!!
from 147 citizens (Petition No. EN0522)
Animal Welfare

Puppy farms are commonly large-scale commercial operations, with inadequate conditions that may also exist in small volume breeding establishments which may or may not be run for profit. Puppy farming is confirmed as major animal welfare issue in Australia. Problems associated with puppy farms include but are not limited to: Extreme confinement
Inadequate veterinary care and general care.
Unhygienic living conditions.
Inadequate and overcrowded kennel conditions.

Frequent long-term health and/or behavioural problems. On December the 15th, 2017, Victorian parliament passed the The Domestic Animals Amendment (Puppy Farm and Pet Shops) Act (the PFPS Act). This was implemented to ensure that pet shops are responsibly sourcing their animals, and mills are practicing healthy and safe procedures. Under the amended Act:
there are limits on the number of fertile female dogs breeders can keep
pet shops are only able to sell animals sourced from shelters, pounds or enrolled foster carers
the role of foster carers is clearer
there are new definitions for 'recreational breeders' and 'micro-breeders'
the definition of 'farm working dogs' is clarified
the animal sale permit system is simplified
traceability of animals will be improved through the establishment of the Pet Exchange Register
offences apply for publishing noncompliant pet sale advertisements. All standards will be implemented by the year 2020.
I request of the House of Representatives that Victorias State (PFPS Act) be made Federal across Australia, to ensure consistent safeguards and animal welfare standards.
from 49 citizens (Petition No. EN0553)
Child Protection

Inhumane acts to children need tougher penalties including death penalty. Protected custody is not sufficient for monsters harming children. This is in response to the breaking new system involving the 8yr old girl and swingers club.
We therefore ask the house to act on tougher penalties including death penalty for inhuman and indecent sexual acts to children
from 30 citizens (Petition No. EN0556)
Australian Broadcasting Corporation

The federal government awards the Australian Broadcasting Corporation $1 billion in funding per year. It is therefore the responsibility of the ABC to represent the people and not to push an ideological agenda onto the children of our great nation nor to bully the men and women of Australia who object to said agenda. This is exactly what 2 productions of the ABC (ABC Comedy and ABC Me) have done with their recently released "Internet Song", "What its like:" and "Privilege Rap" among other examples. This behaviour is not only morally reprehensible but is also in breach of Australian broadcasting Corporation Act of 1983 which states: "to ensure that the gathering and presentation by the Corporation of news and information is accurate and impartial according to the recognized standards of objective journalism;".
We therefore ask the House to investigate the ABC for misuse of funds for the purposes of pushing an agenda and to drastically cut the ABC's funding by 90%.
from 40 citizens (Petition No. EN0562)
Plastic Straws

There's an estimated 150 million tonnes of plastic spread throughout the world's ocean already, increasing by the equivalent of a garbage truck full of plastic every minute worldwide. Recent studies indicate that by 2050, the amount of plastic in the ocean will outweigh fish. Among the top 10 items found in the ocean are plastic straws and stirrers. Most recycling facilities don't process the type of plastic used in plastic straws, which means most end up either in landfill or washed down stormwater drains and into the ocean when not properly disposed of. To put that in perspective: over 10 million plastic straws are used in Australia every single day. Feasible, alternate options to plastic straws already exist and include eco-friendly biodegradable straws, some of which can decompose within 35 days of use. Plastic straws on the other hand take approximately 200 years to break down.
Ban Plastic Straws at take away outlets, drinking establishments and restaurants in Australia.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN0564)
Ivory Trade

Tens of thousands of elephants are still being slaughtered every year for their ivory. This rate of poaching is pushing African elephants ever closer to extinction, and the window of opportunity for saving them is rapidly shrinking. Since poaching for the ivory trade is the most pressing threat facing Africa's elephants and rhinos, the closure of all ivory markets, both international and domestic, is critical for their survival. Global ivory trade and poaching accounts for almost $15 to 20 billion annually. Illegal trade in wildlife is a lucrative market for criminals. While Australia has banned import of ivory, thousands of ivory items are sold (domestically) each year through auction houses, often without documentation proving whether they are genuine antiques. This allows ivory to be illegally imported through other means.

There is a long-standing ban on ivory being imported into Australia, but it is perfectly legal to buy and sell ivory items domestically. Domestic ivory trade must also be banned as it encourages illegal imports. Tough penalties should also be imposed to protect the illegal trade.
from 6 citizens (Petition No. EN0565)
Migration

The Social Security (Assurance of Support) Determination 2018 (F2018L00425) made on 26 March 2018 amended the financial criteria to be met for people giving assurances of support for 143 visa. Under the new legislation, a single Australian citizen or Permanent Resident who wishes to be the assurer for his or her overseas parents must have an annual income of at least $86,606.52. Nevertheless, people who have a spouse or children will face even higher income threshold. Such change undermines the intrinsic value of family relationships and the principle of equity. Moreover, grandparents can provide childcare allowing sponsors to go from being one-income to two-income households, which takes pressure off the welfare system. This policy opens Australia's migration law up to the charge of being directed more towards the rich and unflavored the underprivileged. Furthermore, people who have lodged their applications for 143 visa before 1 April 2018 are in confusion since there is no transitional policy imposed.
I ask the house to restore to the previous annual income standard.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN0570)
Body Scan

No choice when it comes to Full Body Scanners in Australian airports. Citizens should have a choice of whether to undergo a Full Body Scan or to opt-out for a Full Body Pat-down. This choice is offered in airports overseas and it should be offered here. Reasons for not wanting Body Scan is not wanting to go through equipment that emits radiation.
We therefore ask the House to legislate that passengers be given a choice to either undergo a Full Body Scan or to have a Full Body-pat
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN0571)
Migration

I submitted my Contributory Parent Visa (Subclass 143) on May 2015. Its is unfair for people like me already waited for 3 years and contribute so much just want to get my family reunion. I am a working class that contribute my tax for the benefit of Australia and I will defend my right for my family well-being.
Requesting that the House to grant exemption or strike down the increasing of Assurance of Support (AOS) for Contributory parent Visa (subclass 143) application lodged before 01/04/2018.
from 3 citizens (Petition No. EN0578)
Migration

On 26 March 2018, The Minter for Social Services has made a significant change to the Assurance of Support scheme (AoS) and it comes into effect immediately from 1 April 2018. It had affected all Australian Citizens and Permanent Residents who have submitted Parents immigration applications 143/173/864/103 for the family reunion. The new change: 1. Gives No Transition Period for the existing immigration applicants. (The current visa 143 application had waited for more than three years to be allocated to the case officer, which was list as 1.5 years when applied in 2015) 2. Has not been officially announced to the public before came into effect. Human service and immigration departments provided inconsistent information and reported have not trained for this. 3. Has doubled the financial requirement which is over the statistically Australian average income. Regardless of the willingness of partners to be involved in assurance or its finical independence, the number of partners are included in the calculation. 4. Requires the years (dated back to last 3 years, previously 2 years)of income evidence, ALL to meet the new AoS.

We, therefore, ask the house to strike down the new AoS scheme. At least a transitional policy to be imposed for existing immigration applicants who lodged the application for visa 143/864/173/103 before 1 April 2018. Allowing them to be accessed with the previous scheme when allocated to the case officer for AoS. A more reasonable calculation showing consideration of partner's willingness, average income, assets, prolonged process period when asking for longer income evidence.
from 4 citizens (Petition No. EN0580)
Child Support

We, as Citizens of Australia, are requesting that the House enact a law recognising that Parental Alienation is child abuse. The act of denying a child access to his/her parent should be classified as illegal Parental Alienation. Also that this should incur a penalty by those found guilty of perpetrating Parental Alienation upon a child.

We therefor ask the House to recognise the act of denying a child access to his/her parent should be classified as illegal Parental Alienation. Also that this should incur a penalty by those found guilty of perpetrating Parental Alienation upon a child. This penalty would be decided upon by the House but we would ask that, at a minimum, the penalty should involve forfeiture of any and all right to Child Support payments for that period (or backpay for said period) until such time as access resumes.
from 1,591 citizens (Petition No. EN0581)
Live Animal Exports

We have seen photographic evidence of neglect and callous disregard for the basic welfare of animals by the operators of vessels used for the export of live sheep from Australian ports to overseas destinations in the Middle East. The live sheep export trade materially benefits the farmers and exporters who shamelessly consign their animals to these operators for profit regardless of the suffering it causes. It benefits those overseas traders who capitalise on the misery of animals which lack protection of any kind from unspeakable acts of cruelty and barbarism both during their sea voyage and onshore upon arrival. If, as a nation, we are to describe ourselves as 'civilised' then the live sheep export trade cannot be allowed to continue in any form.
We therefore ask the House to ban the export of live sheep from Australia.
from 46 citizens (Petition No. EN0585)
Incandescent Light Bulbs

Since energy efficient lighting standards started and the phase out of standard incandescent light bulbs, people with light sensitivity conditions have suffered worldwide including in Australia. Restricting standard incandescent light bulbs can impact on the social and community life of people with light sensitivity conditions. Even modern energy efficient homes with the amount of wattage in lighting being restricted are not suitable for light sensitivity conditions. Light covers are not enough to stop harsh cool and daylight coloured lighting in places like shops and shopping centres. For people with sensitivity to flickering bulbs, the use of CFLs or LEDs can trigger problems – either from the bulbs normal operation or when they fail. In the case of people with Irlen Syndrome the best lighting is indirect natural lighting or incandescent lighting. I have autism and I have been affected by energy efficient lighting to which sunglasses or Irlen lenses do not resolve the problem – I still experience sensory overload. I experience sensory overload in any area that has energy efficient lighting. The National Disability Strategy 2010-2020 wants to achieve "inclusive and accessible communities" for people with disabilities to succeed in life..

(1) Abolish sales restrictions of standard incandescent light bulbs (2) Allow unrestricted importing of GLS incandescent bulbs (3) Have all public buildings cater for light sensitivity by using standard incandescent light bulbs and warm linear or circular fluorescent tubes. (4) Abolish energy efficiency requirements for residential, business and industrial buildings.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN0590)
Child Support

That parents continue to make child support payments after their child turns 18 years old until they earn enough to reach the tax threshold, complete training, study or turn 21years old whichever comes first.

We therefore ask the House to modify current practice that releases parents of responsibility to provide for their families. (As most 18yr olds live at home single parents, supplemented by Government payments, bare the costs of living rather than both parents.)
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN0593)
National Broadband Network
Requesting reversal of permission of a proposal to install an nbn fixed wireless facility at 139 Fifth Avenue Llandilo NSW 2747 (Lot 1 on DP 233427)

We ask the house to step in and assist the residence surrounding the property of 139 Fifth Avenue Llandilo NSW 747 (Lot 1 on DP 233427) to halt the progress of installing eight panel antennas and one radio communications dish antenna onto a proposed 45 meter monopole. The property of 139 Fifth Avenue Llandilo NSW 2747 (Lot 1 on DP 233427) is surrounded by homes and not to mention is only 3 minutes away from our local school, Llandilo Public School at Seventh Avenue Llandilo NSW 2747. Llandilo already has a communication tower situated on Sixth Avenue Llandilo NSW 2747, but has a 40 acre clearing surrounding the tower. This proposed tower homes are close and there is no clearing which is a concern for everyone's health and well being. We personally do not need another communication tower within Llandilo, one is enough.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN0594)
M1 Pacific Motorway

This problem with the M1 between Garden City and Robina is going to get much worse before it gets better. The population is growing and the roads can not keep up. Please let's get some signatures so we can show the government just how much of an inconvenience this is becoming.
Expand the M1 from Garden City to Robina Now. Don't drop the speed limit.
from 7 citizens (Petition No. EN0595)
Cannabis

An average 72% of respondents polled in April 2018 agreed with the Australian Green's proposal to legalise Cannabis for adult use and the right to home cultivation. Over one third of Australians admit to using Cannabis but indications are that many more use it covertly on a regular basis and would only admit the same in a secret ballot. Laws prohibiting personal use, possession and cultivation of Cannabis have been ineffective, and have effectively ruined the lives of many otherwise law-abiding citizens. They have driven users to the black market and allowed criminals to flourish, putting public safety at great risk. This is counter to current harm reduction policy. Societal harms and deaths from alcohol and illicit/prescription drug abuse have noticeably reduced in jurisdictions where Cannabis has been legalised. It is not unreasonable to expect similar in Australia. We acknowledge Australia is bound by outdated international treaty obligations, but note many nations have moved forward, basing decisions on current scientific evidence that disputes 'reefer madness' propaganda on which prohibition of Cannabis was based, last century. Economically, taxpayer funds currently expended on police/judicial resources to enforce Cannabis laws could be better utilised elsewhere, while taxation from sales of legal Cannabis has the potential to raise millions of dollars. Essentially the benefits far outweigh the risks.
We therefore request a plebiscite be held at the next Federal Election asking: "Should the herb Cannabis sativa L., be legalised for adult use Australia-wide?
from 12,881 citizens (Petition No. EN0596)
Stem Cell

Suggesting that the House revise their decisions to keep the Autologous Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation (AHSCT) for sufferers of Multiple Sclerosis (MS) in the 'experimental' category. The reason for this request is due to the large number of people suffering with MS in Australia being unable to receive the treatment in their own country due to two major factors: 1. The trials of AHSCT are only being run in two hospitals in Australia and one of these hospital's trial for the treatment doesn't solely focus on it's success for MS patients. 2. The criteria for an individual to be granted access to this trial in Australia is very strict which means that only a very small number of people with MS can undergo the treatment. Current medications and treatments that Australia has to offer for MS sufferers include medications like Tysabri (Natalizumab). These treatments have been used for years in Australia despite obvious health risks, for example, Tysabri's biggest health risks include; increased risk of Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) and possible Death. Despite the huge risks these treatments are allowed by the Australian Health Ethics Committee, so why can't AHSCT be allowed in Australia for those suffering from MS?

We therefore ask the House to allow Autologous Haematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation to be used as treatment for MS so that sufferers of the disease can undergo AHSCT in their home country (Australia) by following the criteria that the A.A. Maximov Department of Hematology and Cellular Therapy use for patients with Multiple Sclerosis.
from 108 citizens (Petition No. EN0598)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:02): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Victorian Electricity Distribution Networks
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning a petition on removing the monopoly market from the five Victorian electricity distribution networks (petition number EN0297).

While the Australian Government (the Government) has a leadership role in energy policy, state and territory governments retain primary responsibility for energy issues. The wholesale market, transmission and distribution networks and retail markets are currently regulated by the Australian Energy Regulator (AER) under the National Electricity Laws and Rules. In accordance with the National Electricity Objective, the regulatory framework seeks to deliver services in the long term interests of consumers in terms of price, quality, safety, reliability and security of supply across all sectors of the market. The AER is equipped with powers to investigate and enforce compliance with the national energy legislation.

The current electricity market framework encourages competition where it is likely to deliver efficient outcomes, for example in the generation and retail sectors. However, electricity networks are a natural monopoly. The high capital cost of electricity networks make it efficient to have a single provider of network services in a particular geographic area. Having multiple distribution network providers across the five Victorian distribution market areas would increase costs for consumers. To protect customers from paying too much for monopoly network service providers, the AER regulates their revenue, setting a ceiling on the costs they can recover through electricity bills.

The Government understands community concern about rising electricity prices and has sought to improve regulation across the energy sector. The Government has boosted the AER's funding by $67.4 million and provided it with additional market monitoring powers. We have also improved the network regulation process by abolishing the Limited Merits Review regime, which allowed network businesses to increase electricity bills by appealing the AER's decisions.
The Treasurer has also asked the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to review retail electricity prices. The review will consider, among other things, the

competitiveness of offers available to larger business customers, and take into account wholesale electricity market conduct, price and cost issues. The ACCC Retail Electricity Pricing Inquiry: Preliminary Report was published on 16 October 2017; its final report due 30 June 2018.

Regarding the setting of solar feed in tariffs, the COAG Energy Council has agreed that feed in tariffs should reflect the fair value of the electricity exported by the household. In Victoria, the Essential Services Commission calculates a minimum rate, currently 11.3 cents per kilowatt hour, which retailers must pay (although retailers may offer a higher amount). The costs of premium feed in tariff rates that pay a rate significantly above the fair value of electricity are recovered from other consumers and contribute to higher prices.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment And Energy, The Hon Josh Frydenberg MP
Carbon Mitigation
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter regarding a petition concerning carbon mitigation strategies and electricity costs, reference number EN0301.

Climate change is a global issue that requires international action. The Australian Government (the Government) is playing its role in addressing climate change, while ensuring we maintain energy security and affordability and a strong economy. The Paris Agreement is a landmark collective global response to the threat of climate change. It has been ratified by 170 parties to the UNFCCC, accounting for 86 per cent of global emissions and 90 per cent of the world's population. This reaffirms our commitment to effective international action on climate change, including Australia's target to reduce emissions to 26-28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030.

The Government is moving forward with a plan to deliver an affordable and reliable energy system that will also help meet our international commitments. The National Energy Guarantee (the Guarantee) is a mechanism designed to bring together energy and climate policy, while maintaining system reliability. The Guarantee is a credible pro-market policy that does not involve subsidies or taxes. It is estimated to reduce household electricity bills by an average of $120 per year from 2020. The Guarantee will encourage new investment in the lowest cost technologies, making energy more affordable for households and businesses.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment And Energy, The Hon Josh Frydenberg MP
Australia's Federal Parliament
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 6 February 2018 regarding Petition EN0401, which asks the House to clarify the name of Australia's Federal Parliament and a number of associated matters. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this petition to my attention.
Consistent with longstanding practice, it would not be appropriate for me to provide or disclose legal advice to the Committee. However, the following information may be of assistance.

Section 1 of the Constitution provides that the 'legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament, which shall consist of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives, and which is hereinafter called The Parliament, or The Parliament of the Commonwealth'. Section 1 does not provide that the Parliament it establishes shall only be known as 'The Parliament' or 'The Parliament of the Commonwealth'. This can be compared to covering clause 3 of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act, which provides that the people of each State 'shall be united in a Federal Commonwealth under the name of the Commonwealth of Australia.'

The Commonwealth Parliament, Parliament of Australia and Parliament of the Commonwealth are sometimes used interchangeably. Section 2B of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 (Cth) provides 'In Any Act: ... Parliament means the Parliament of the Commonwealth'.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, The Hon Christian Porter MP
Royal Style and Titles Act 1973
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 6 February 2018 referring the above petition to the Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, for response. I have been asked to reply on the Prime Minister's behalf

The case contended in the petition, that the Royal Style and Titles Act 1973 (the 1973 RST Act) and its relation to the oaths a monarch takes upon accession to the throne has in some way led to defective government, is not well founded.

The inquiry in part concerns the Australian Parliament's authority to alter the Royal Style and Titles. To that end, it is useful to refer to the preamble to the Royal Style and Titles Act 1953 which recites matters informing that authority, including the following (in summary):

whereas the preamble to the Statute of Westminster 1931 recites that it would accord with the established constitutional position of all the members of the British Commonwealth of Nations that any alteration in the law touching the Royal Style and Titles should, after the enactment of that Statute, 'require the assent as well of the Parliaments of all the Dominions as of the Parliament of the United Kingdom',

that, in December 1952, it had been agreed between the Prime Ministers and other representatives of the Commonwealth governments that the then Style and Titles did not accord with current constitutional relationships within the British Commonwealth and that a new form was needed to 'reflect the special position of the Sovereign as Head of the Commonwealth',

that, it was further agreed it would accord 'with the established constitutional position that each member country should use for its own purposes a form of the Royal Style and Titles which suits its own particular circumstances but retains a common description of the Sovereign as 'Queen of Her other Realms and Territories and Head of the Commonwealth', and

that it was also agreed that if any country of the British. Commonwealth proposed a change in the form of the Royal Style and Titles there would be consultation between all the Commonwealth governments.

As those recitals contemplate, with the exception of standard references to Her Majesty The Queen's title as 'Head of the Commonwealth' and to the Queen's 'other Realms and Territories', each member country can use a form of Royal Style and Titles to suit its own particular circumstances, which can also be changed.

To the extent the inquiry is concerned with the 'effect' of the 1973 RST Act, that Act enacts the Australian Parliament's assent to the adoption by Her Majesty The Queen of the current form of Royal Style and Titles for use in Australia and its territories. That form, which refers in part to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II as Queen of Australia and Head of the Commonwealth, is consistent with Australia's independence, its establishment as a constitutional monarchy and its membership in the Commonwealth of Nations.

In the second reading speech for the Royal Style and Titles Bill 1973, on 24 May 1973, the then Prime Minister, the Hon Gough Whitlam AC QC, said 'it is appropriate that [the changes] be made with the consent and approval of both the Houses of the Parliament [as it] is they which, with Her Majesty, are able to express in form of law the appropriate description of the constitutional position of the Queen'.

As a result of Section 42 of the Australian Constitution and the attached note in the Schedule to the Constitution, the change to the Royal Style and Titles has no effect on the oaths or affirmations taken by Senators and Members of Parliament.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Prime Minister's attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before the Parliament.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister To The Prime Minister, Senator The Hon James McGrath
Royal Style and Titles Act 1973
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 6 February 2018 referring the above petition to the Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, for response. I have been asked to reply on the Prime Minister's behalf.

The purpose of the Royal Style and Titles Act 1973 was for the Australian Parliament to assent to the adoption by Her Majesty The Queen of the form of Royal Style and Titles for use in Australia and its territories. The form of Royal Style and Titles as it applies to Australia is consistent with Australia's independence, its establishment as a constitutional monarchy and its membership in the Commonwealth of Nations.

Under Australia's Constitution, the Parliament has the power to make laws for the Commonwealth of Australia, but laws that have passed both Houses of the Parliament require the Royal Assent before they are enacted. Following the passage of the Royal Style and Titles Bill 1973 through both Houses of the Parliament, Her Majesty The Queen personally gave Her assent to that Bill on 19 October 1973. As such the following Royal Style and Titles is the form that applies to the Commonwealth of Australia and its territories (which, as it applies in this Act, has the same meaning as Australia and its territories):
Elizabeth the Second, by the Grace of God Queen of Australia and Her other Realms and Territories, Head of the Commonwealth.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Prime Minister's attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before the Parliament.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister To The Prime Minister, Senator The Hon James McGrath
Section 59 of the Constitution
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 6 February 2018 regarding Petition EN0404, which asks the House to clarify what the correct process is for the people to initiate the disallowance of a law by the Queen under section 59 of the Constitution. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Consistent with longstanding practice, it would not be appropriate for me to provide or disclose legal advice to the Committee. A clarification in the terms sought by the petitioner would necessarily entail the provision of legal advice about the operation of section 59 of the Constitution.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, The Hon Christian Porter MP
Defence Force Ombudsman
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 6 February 2018 referring the above petition to the Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, for response. I have been asked to reply on the Prime Minister's behalf.
The Commonwealth Ombudsman investigates complaints from people who believe they have been treated unfairly or unreasonably by an Australian Government agency.

The Ombudsman is responsible for ensuring that administrative decisions made by Government are fair and accountable. The Ombudsman cannot override decisions of agencies, however aims to resolve matters through consultation and negotiation.

Complaints from serving or former members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) are investigated by the Defence Force Ombudsman. The office may also consider specific requests from Defence to undertake complex or sensitive investigations.
Similarly, the Defence Force Ombudsman can make recommendations about administrative decisions made by Defence.

From 1 December 2016 the role of the Defence Force Ombudsman was expanded to include an abuse reporting function for serving and former Defence members, and civilians deployed on operations. This provides a confidential mechanism to report sexual abuse,
serious physical abuse and serious bullying and harassment within Defence, for those who feel unable to access Defence's internal mechanisms.

The ADF is responsible for the protection of the nation and operates in unique circumstances. Due to the nature of military service, the conditions and allowances for members of the ADF are complex and vastly different to those for members of the Australian Public Service.

If an ADF member is not satisfied with an administrative decision made by the ADF they can escalate their concerns through their chain of command. Alternatively they can contact the personnel management unit in their respective Service.

ADF members also have access to the Redress of Grievance process which is a legislated framework by which they can submit formal complaints about matters that relate to their military service. All complaints under this process are given fresh consideration on the merits in order to reach a decision on the issue separate to any decision made at first instance by the chain of command. The process is overseen by the Inspector-General of the ADF who is a statutory office holder, accountable to the Minister, and who operates independently from the normal chain of command. Under the legislation, the Inspector-General of the ADF must consider every complaint and may make findings and recommendations including the provision of a report to relevant parties and any Defence officials whose actions might be required to grant the redress.

In addition to this internal audit and review function, the Inspector General of the ADF provides the Chief of the Defence Force with an avenue by which alleged failures of the system, systemic or otherwise, may be examined and brought to the attention of command as necessary.

Legal Assistance is available to ADF members for matters related to ADF service. Examples include questioning/charging under the Defence Force Discipline Act, Redress of Grievances, Replies to Notice to Show Cause and Termination Notices, affected persons under inquiry or investigation and Medical Employment Classification Review Board.

External to Defence, members may access the Ombudsman, the Australian Human Rights Commission on matters about unlawful discrimination and breaches of human rights, or seek judicial review of decisions through the Federal courts. In the latter case, the Federal courts have the power to revoke decisions affecting members.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Prime Minister's attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before the Parliament.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister To The Prime Minister, Senator The Hon James McGrath
Australian National Anthem
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 6 February 2018 referring the above petition to the Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, for response. I have been asked to reply on the Prime Minister's behalf.

The words and tune of the Australian National Anthem were adopted only after exhaustive surveys of national opinion, starting in the 1970s, and were proclaimed by the Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia on 19 April 1984.
The Australian National Anthem is widely accepted and popularly supported by a majority of Australians. The Australian Government has no plans to change the Anthem.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Prime Minister's attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before the Parliament.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister To The Prime Minister, Senator The Hon James McGrath
Climate Change
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN0421, in relation to geoengineering and weather modification to prevent climate change.

The Australian Government (the Government) accepts the science of climate change and takes its primary advice on climate science from the Bureau of Meteorology and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Office. This advice aligns with information provided by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and other national and international organisations.

The Government is providing strong action on climate change, including through policies like the Emissions Reduction Fund (the ERF). The ERF encourages activities to store carbon through land-use changes such as afforestation, reforestation and soil carbon sequestration. To date, Emissions Reduction Fund projects have secured over 190 million tonnes of emissions reductions, which will contribute to Australia's 2020 and 2030 emissions reduction targets.

Australia is also working internationally to ensure the appropriate regulation of geo-engineering activities. For example, Australia led international negotiations to determine amendments to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and other Matter 1997 (the London Protocol) to regulate ocean fertilisation activities.
For more detail on the Government's action on climate change, visit: http://environment.gov.au/climate-change.
Thank you again for your letter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment And Energy, The Hon Josh Frydenberg MP
Royal Style and Titles Act 1953
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 6 February 2018 referring the above petition to the Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, for response. I have been asked to reply on the Prime Minister's behalf.

Through the Royal Style and Titles Act 1953 the Australian Parliament assented to the adoption by Her Majesty The Queen of the following form of Royal Style and Titles for use in Australia and its territories:
Elizabeth the Second, by the Grace of God of the United Kingdom, Australia and Her other Realms and Territories Queen, Head of the Commonwealth, Defender of the Faith.

Through the Royal Style and Titles Act 1973 the Australian Parliament assented to the adoption by Her Majesty The Queen of the following changed form of Royal Style and Titles for use in Australia and its territories:
Elizabeth the Second, by the Grace of God Queen of Australia and Her other Realms and Territories, Head of the Commonwealth.
Her Majesty The Queen gave Her personal assent to each of those Acts and, by proclamations, adopted the above forms of Royal Style and Titles for use in relation to Australia and its territories.

The inquiry in part concerns the Australian Parliament's authority to alter the Royal Style and Titles. To that end, it is useful to refer to the preamble to the Royal Style and Titles Act 1953 which recites matters informing that authority, including the following (in summary):whereas the preamble to the Statute of Westminster 1931 recites that it would accord with the established constitutional position of all the members of the British Commonwealth of Nations that any alteration in the law touching the Royal Style and Titles should, after the enactment of that Statute, 'require the assent as well of the Parliaments of all the Dominions as of the Parliament of the United Kingdom',

that, in December 1952, it had been agreed between the Prime Ministers and other representatives of the Commonwealth governments that the then Style and Titles did not accord with current constitutional relationships within the British Commonwealth and that a new form was needed to 'reflect the special position of the Sovereign as Head of the Commonwealth',

that, it was further agreed it would accord 'with the established constitutional position that each member country should use for its own purposes a form of the Royal Style and Titles which suits its own particular circumstances but retains a common description of the Sovereign as 'Queen of Her other Realms and Territories and Head of the Commonwealth', and

that it was also agreed that if any country of the British Commonwealth proposed a change in the form of the Royal Style and Titles there would be consultation between all the Commonwealth governments.

As those recitals contemplate, with the exception of standard references to Her Majesty The Queen's title as 'Head of the Commonwealth' and to the Queen's 'other Realms and Territories', each member country can use a form of Royal Style and Titles to suit its own particular circumstances, which can also be changed.

On 1 May 1973, in a ministerial statement, the then Prime Minister, the Hon Gough Whitlam AC QC, foreshadowed his Government's intention to introduce a Bill to change the Royal Style and Titles in the 1953 Act. Mr Whitlam stated he had spoken to Her Majesty The Queen and had Her "... full concurrence in an amendment, if the Australian Parliament approves, which would result in dropping the specific reference to the United Kingdom and the reference 'Defender of the Faith'. Explaining that the 1953 formulation was 'not now sufficiently distinctively Australian', Mr Whitlam also said that the 'Defender of the Faith' reference 'has no historical or constitutional relevance in Australia'.

Subsequently, the Royal Style and Titles Bill 1973 was introduced into the House of Representatives on 24 May 1973. In the second reading speech, Mr Whitlam reiterated that the reference to 'Defender of the Faith' had no historical or constitutional relevance for Australia.

As a final observation, I note that the term 'Defender of the Faith' is not used in the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act. The form of Royal Style and Titles adopted for Australia is consistent with Australia's independence, its establishment as a constitutional monarchy and its membership in the Commonwealth of Nations.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Prime Minister's attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before the Parliament.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister To The Prime Minister, Senator The Hon James McGrath
Refugee
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 6 February 2018 referring the above petition to the Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, for response. I have been asked to reply on the Prime Minister's behalf.

The Australian Government takes its legal obligations seriously and is committed to acting in accordance with domestic and international law. While the Government's border protection policies — including regional processing — are tough, they are necessary to secure Australia's borders, stamp out people smuggling and prevent people risking their lives at sea. Addressing irregular migration through strong border policies has also restored confidence in the integrity of, and support for, Australia's generous humanitarian resettlement program.

The management of people transferred to Papua New Guinea (PNG) under regional processing arrangements is the responsibility of the Government of PNG. All refugees and non-refugees on Manus Island are housed at PNG-operated accommodation and have access to essential services such as food, water, security and medical services.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Prime Minister's attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before the Parliament.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister To The Prime Minister, Senator The Hon James McGrath
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Dear Mrs Wicks
I refer to your letter of 26 March 2018 concerning petition number EN0454 regarding the cost of Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) prescriptions for Australians under the age of 18.
The petition called for lowering of the price of PBS prescription medications to $5.30 for Australians under the age of 18.

The Australian Government is committed to providing affordable access to necessary medicines for all Australians. PBS medications are available to all Australian residents who hold a current Medicare card. Eligible patients will pay a co-payment of up to $39.50 per prescription or up to $6.40 per prescription if they hold a concession card.

A PBS medication for an Australian under the age of 18 can be obtained at the concession card rate if they or their parent hold a health care card or low income health care card. Further, a holder of one of these cards can ask their pharmacist to pass on the allowable $1.00 discount which would result in a co-payment of $5.40.

There are a wide range of circumstances that would enable an Australian under the age of 18 or their parent or guardian to obtain a health care card. These circumstances include: personal income below $552 dollars per week; being a recipient of Youth Allowance; or a parent being a recipient of the highest rate of Family Tax Benefit Part A.
Details about eligibility for health care cards and how to apply are available on the Department of Human Services website at www.humanservices.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, The Hon Greg Hunt MP
Immigration Detention
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 March 2018 enclosing Petition EN0480, concerning visits to immigration detention facilities (IDFs).
The Department of Home Affairs welcomes visitors into its 1DFs and recognises that visits to detainees are important to their health and well-being.

The Department, through its operational arm, the Australian Border Force (ABF), strives to create a secure immigration detention network (IDN) and a safe environment for detainees, visitors and employees, and implements policies, procedures and processes designed to mitigate identified risks, whilst making its processes as simple, efficient and stress-free as possible.

While Australia's immigration detention population previously comprised mainly illegal maritime arrivals, the current profile indicates that those who have had their visas cancelled under the character provisions of section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 predominate. Of the latter group, many have been found guilty of serious criminal offences.

On 11 September 2017, a revised outside food policy was implemented across the ION. The Department is aware that various food items have been used to smuggle contraband into IDFs in the past. Under the revised policy, visitors are welcome to bring food to share within designated visitors' areas, on the condition that it is commercially packaged and labelled, factory sealed with a valid expiry date and not contained in any metal or glass packaging. These measures ensure crucial food health and safety standards are maintained and enhance the security of detainees, staff and visitors.
The Department already caters for various cultural and individual needs through its catering services within the IDN and detainees are able to contribute suggestions to the creation of the menus.
Around 10,000 people visit IDFs across Australia every month. Set visiting times are necessary to ensure that all detainees have fair and equitable access to visitors.

On 22 January 2018, changes to the visitors' management policy came into effect to increase the safety of all visitors, detainees and staff, including by ensuring that the Department has accurate information about the identity of people seeking to enter an 1DF. The Department must be sure that the people coming into immigration detention facilities are who they say they are and can be properly risk assessed.

Visitors who are 18 years or older seeking to visit an IDF must provide 100 points of identity documents (ID), including photo ID. An ID guideline was introduced as the standard for the entry of personal visitors into IDFs and is available on the Department's website at: http://www.homeaffairs.gov.autabout/immigration­detention-in-australia/detention-facilities/visiting-an-immigration-detention-facility. If an individual has concerns about the ability to produce the required ID, they may contact the local particular facility.

Prior to the implementation of the revised visitor policy and the introduction of the online application system, the Department consulted widely with stakeholders, including but not limited to, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Australian Human Rights Commission (AHRC) and the Australian Red Cross (ARC).

Visitor applications for personal visitors are to be lodged online five business days before the proposed visit. The online visitor application has simplified and streamlined the process for visitors to an 1DF.

If the online option is not readily accessible, a paper application can still be lodged with the relevant IDF. In certain circumstances (short-term detention, emergency, long-distance visitors, or other compassionate reasons), applications for a personal visit lodged less than five days before the proposed visit date may be considered at the discretion of the local ABF Detention Superintendent.

Family or friends wishing to visit a person in immigration detention can obtain information on the Department's website. Information for volunteers, advocacy and community groups, including school groups, wishing to visit multiple detainees is also available.
Visitors are able to bring some items into an 1DF, including games and art supplies, however, certain conditions apply. Further information is available at:
https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/about/immigration-detention-in-australia/detention­facilltles/items-not-permitted-in-detention-facilities.

Services provided at IDFs in Australia are subject to parliamentary scrutiny and accountability. IDFs are regularly visited by the Australian Human Rights Commission, and the Commonwealth Ombudsman's Office, both of which can investigate complaints and advise the Department on possible improvements. The Australian Research Council also conducts periodic humanitarian visits to all IDFs and provides the Department with recommendations.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for immigration and border protection, The Hon Peter Dutton MP
Immunisation
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 26 March 2018 regarding petition number EN0481. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government considers immunisation an important health measure for children and their families as it is the safest and most effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases. This is a public health issue. The Government has determined that while parents have the right to decide not to vaccinate their children, their decision will not be endorsed by the provision of taxpayer funds in the form of the Child Care Benefit, Child Care Rebate or the Family Tax Benefit Part A end-of-year supplement. It is important to note that children with medical contraindications or natural immunity (certified by an appropriate medical practitioner) are exempt from the requirements.

The overwhelming body of medical and scientific evidence supports the promotion of vaccination for the prevention of potentially crippling, debilitating and deadly diseases. All vaccines used in Australia are thoroughly tested for safety and effectiveness, and are rigorously tested on thousands of people in progressively larger clinical trials.

While vaccines, like other medicines, can have side effects, all vaccines used in Australia provide benefits that greatly outweigh the small risk of an adverse event. The majority of side effects following immunisation are minor and short-lived, the most common being local reactions at the injection site, fever or tiredness. Serious side effects from vaccination are extremely rare. Adverse events following immunisation at any age should be reported through the usual reporting mechanisms in your state or territory or to the Therapeutic Goods Administration through the 'report a problem' link via its website at www.tga.gov.au. Legislation for this measure was passed through Parliament on 23 November 2015 and was accompanied by a Statement of Compatibility with Human Rights, in accordance with the Government's normal process. The measure was also examined by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights, which reported in its human rights scrutiny report, the Thirty-seventh Report of the 44th Parliament, tabled on 2 May 2016 that the measure is compatible with international human rights law.
For more information about the No Jab, No Pay measure go to www.humanservices.gov.au/immunisation. For more information about childhood immunisation in Australia go to www.immunise.health.gov.au.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours Sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, The Hon Dan Tehan MP
Maritime Boundary
Dear Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 28 March 2018 regarding petition PN0080 on the maritime boundary between Australia and Timor-Leste.

On 6 March 2018, I was pleased to sign an historic treaty establishing permanent maritime boundaries between Australia and Timor-Leste. The treaty was brokered by the Conciliation Commission established under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) - which was the first of its kind.
The UNCLOS Commission and both parties agree the treaty is balanced,

equitable and consistent with international law. Timor-Leste's Chief Negotiator, Kay Rala Xanana Gusmao, said the treaty establishes "a fair border between our two countries, based on international law".

The treaty delivers benefits for both countries. Australia and Timor-Leste have agreed that we will exercise joint rights over the seabed containing the Greater Sunrise field. Seventy or eighty per cent of the revenue from developing Greater Sunrise will flow to Timor-Leste, depending on the final development concept to be agreed upon by Timor-Leste and Australia.
Additional information on the Timor Sea maritime arrangements can be found on the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade website at http://dfat.gov.au/geo/Timor-Leste/Pages/Timor-Leste.aspx.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, The Hon Julie Bishop MP
Climate Change
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter regarding the twenty petitions received by the Petitions Committee on the impacts of climate change.

The Australian Government (the Government) is taking action on climate change and contributing to global efforts to reduce emissions. As part of the Paris Agreement, Australia has committed to reduce emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. This will see Australia's emissions per person halve and the emissions intensity of our economy reduce by two-thirds. On this basis, Australia's target is among the strongest of major economies.

Addressing the impacts of climate change is a priority for the Pacific region. Through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Government works closely with Pacific island countries and regional organisations to build resilience to the impacts of climate change. We have sustained and increased funding to sectors affected by climate change such as fisheries, and for disaster preparedness.

The Government's policies to reduce emissions are working and we will meet our international commitments. We are reducing emissions through the Emissions Reduction Fund, providing incentives to Australian businesses, communities and farmers for adopting new practices and technologies that reduce emissions. The Renewable Energy Target ensures 23.5 per cent of Australia's electricity comes from renewable sources by 2020 and the National Energy Productivity Plan is reducing emissions through more efficient use of energy. The Government is also helping households install rooftop solar panels and solar hot water systems through rebates under the Renewable Energy Target.

In addition the recently announced National Energy Guarantee (the Guarantee) will require energy retailers and some large users across the National Electricity Market to deliver reliable and lower emissions energy generation each year. The Guarantee is estimated to reduce household electricity bills by an average of $120 per year from 2020. The Government will continue to work with the independent Energy Security Board and the states through the Council of Australian Governments to implement these reforms.

Yours sincerely
from the Minister For The Environment And Energy, The Hon Josh Frydenberg MP

Adani Carmichael Coalmine
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter concerning petition PN0288 presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions regarding the Adani Carmichael coal mine.
The Carmichael Coal Mine and Rail Project was approved on 14 October 2015, in accordance with the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act).
The approval is subject to conditions that take into account issues raised by the community and require the company to meet appropriate environmental standards.

The Carmichael Coal Mine is situated in outback Queensland, approximately 300 kilometres west of the Great Barrier Reef. The mine will not have any direct impacts on the reef. The emissions arising from the use of coal from this and other mines are addressed by national and international measures to deal with climate change more broadly. The complex, global nature of emissions is best addressed with such measures, rather than by trying to connect climate change impacts to individual mining projects.

The Australian Government (the Government) is committed to supporting the transition to a lower emissions economy, while at the same time, providing sustainable, secure and affordable energy to industry and households. The Renewable Energy Target (RET) is a Government scheme designed to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases in the electricity sector by encouraging additional generation of electricity from renewable sources. It is expected to lift the share of renewables to around 23.5 per cent of Australia's electricity generation by 2020.

The Government's strong record on renewable energy has led to an unprecedented wave of investment in renewable energy currently underway, supported by the RET. More new build renewable projects came online in 2017 than in any previous year. Clean energy investment was Australia's highest on record at A$11 billion, which placed Australia 7th of all countries in the world. There was more rooftop solar power installed across Australia than in the history of the renewable energy industry. Australia has the world's highest rate of solar panels, with one in five Australian households now having solar panels on their roof.

Protecting precious water resources from impacts of large coal mines is a priority of the Government. The Carmichael Coal Mine and Rail Project approval includes conditions for the protection of water, including a requirement for Adani to offset the predicted annual water take of the mine.

While the exact number of people estimated to be employed in the Carmichael Coal Mine and Rail project's construction and operational phases is a subject of debate, there is no doubt that the project will create many direct and indirect jobs in Queensland.

The Native Title Act 1993 creates processes through which native title is recognised and protected. This includes a process for native title claimants and holders to enter into voluntaryagreements with third parties in relation to the use of land and waters on native title. These agreements are referred to as Indigenous Land Use Agreements. Adani Mining Pty Ltd and Wangan and Jagalingou people signed the Adani Carmichael Indigenous Land Use Agreement over part of the Carmichael project area. The Native Title Tribunal registered Adani's Indigenous Land Use Agreement on 8 December 2017.

Adani had expressed interest in accessing the $5 billion Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility (NAIF) to support its North Galilee Basin Railway proposal. On 12 December 2017, the NAIF received formal notification from the Queensland Government that financial assistance should not be provided to Adani's North Galilee Basin Rail Project. As a consequence, in accordance with s13(4) of the NAIF Investment Mandate, the NAIF will not be making an investment decision to provide financial assistance to that project.

In making his decision to approve the project, the then Minister for the Environment, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, had regard to the environmental history of Adani Mining Pty Ltd and its related entities. The information considered was sourced from a range of environmental organisations and the company. Consideration of the company's environmental history was the most comprehensive ever undertaken under the EPBC Act.

The EPBC Act establishes a strong framework for protection of the environment and the conservation of biodiversity. It includes a broad range of enforcement mechanisms for managing suspected or identified instances of non-compliance and for reviewing the compliance of referred projects. These mechanisms include:

civil or criminal penalties that can apply to individuals and corporations that contravene the requirements for environmental approvals under the Act, including the provision of false or misleading information to obtain approval,
remediation orders and determinations to repair or mitigate environmental damage resulting from a contravention of the EPBC Act,
enforceable undertakings to negotiate civil penalties and provide for future compliance.
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to thispetition
Yours Sincerely
from the Minister For The Environment And Energy, The Hon Josh Frydenberg MP
Falun Gong
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 26 March 2018 regarding petition number PN0329 calling for an immediate end to the persecution of Falun Gong in China
The Australian Government agrees China's ban on Falun Gong and its treatment of practitioners are in breach of international human rights standards.

We are aware of claims of illegal organ harvesting in China from Falun Gong practitioners. Those claims, if true, are deeply disturbing. While we consider there is insufficient credible evidence to support the Falun Gong's specific allegations, there is little doubt organs have been harvested from executed prisoners for use in medical transplants, at least prior to 2015. Australia strongly opposes this practice.

In 2015, Dr Huang Jiefu, head of China's organ donation committee, announced that only voluntarily donated organs from civilians could be used in transplants from 1 July 2015. While this announcement is welcome, we recognise it will make little difference if it is not properly enforced.

We have raised our concerns over the practice of harvesting organs from executed prisoners directly with the Chinese Government. We will continue to urge China to ensure the 2015 regulations are implemented at all levels.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister of Foreign Affairs, The Hon Julie Bishop MP
Child Protection
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 6 February 2018 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Malcolm Turnbull MP, regarding Petition EN0420 about child protection. Your letter has been referred to me as I have portfolio responsibility for this matter.

The Commonwealth Government acknowledges the importance of ensuring children and young people are safe and well and values the important contribution of kinship and grandparent carers who provide loving homes for children who are unable to live with their parents.

In Australia, state and territory governments have statutory responsibility for the care and protection of children and young people experiencing, or at risk of, abuse or neglect, including the child protection and out-of-home care systems.

However, the number of children suffering abuse and neglect, including the disproportionate number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children affected, is of concern to all governments. As at 30 June 2017, approximately 47,900 children were in out-of-home care. During 2016-17, Aboriginal and Tones Strait Islander children were seven times as likely as non-Indigenous children to have received child protection services, and ten times as likely as non-Indigenous children to be in out-of-home care.

Through the National Framework for Protecting Australia's Children 2009-2020 (the National Framework), the Commonwealth Government is working closely with state and territory governments and the community sector, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations, to address these issues. The Framework's Third Action Plan 2015-18 focuses on prevention and early intervention, to better support families and prevent children coming into contact with the child protection system.

Commonwealth, state and territory Ministers responsible for community services also meet regularly and work collaboratively to drive improvement for children. In August 2017, Ministers unanimously agreed more needs to be done at all levels of government to improve the safety and wellbeing of children and young people, in particular improving access to permanent, safe and stable homes for children in out-of-home care (`permanency'). Ministers confirmed that early intervention and prevention, particularly for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander families, is a priority for all governments.

The petitioners request a Royal Commission into Child Protective Services across Australia. You may be interested to know that the Senate Community Affairs References Committee held an Inquiry into Out-of-Home Care in 2015.

A number of the Inquiry's recommendations are being addressed through the National Framework and Community Services Ministers' permanency reform work. Improving stability and permanency for children in out-of-home care, a key concern of the Inquiry, will be a priority under the forthcoming Fourth Action Plan of the National Framework.

Community Services Ministers have identified the need for greater consistency in achieving permanency outcomes to ensure children in each state and territory receive: safe and stable care; timely decision-making on a permanent family placement that takes into the account their views; and lifelong relationships and a sense of belonging, identity and connection to culture and community.
To this end, the Commonwealth Government is working collaboratively with state and territory governments to lead national permanency reform. Ministers' agreed priorities include:
investing in recruitment of, and support and training for, permanent carers;
national public reporting on permanency timeframes that are achieved;
measuring progress on permanency outcomes through a national data and evaluation framework;
ensuring permanency planning commences as soon as children come into contact with the child protection system to avoid lengthy delays; and
upholding the Aboriginal and Tones Strait Islander Child Placement Principle.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Principle seeks to ensure state and territory child and family welfare policy, legislation and/or practice places importance on connection to family, community, culture and country for Indigenous children and young people. Fundamental to the Principle is the recognition that Aboriginal and Tones Strait Islander people have the knowledge and experience to make the best decisions concerning their children. Of course, the best interests of the child is always the paramount consideration in child protection decision-making.

The petitioners also call for a grandparent carer support person to advocate for them with services. The 2013 Senate Inquiry into Grandparents who take responsibility for Raising their Grandchildren looked into how the role of grandparents raising their grandchildren should be recognised, the challenges they face, and their support needs.

The Australian Government response to this inquiry focused on encouraging greater awareness and use of existing services, and supports available to grandparent carers. Three new initiatives were also noted in the response:
increased support for grandparent and kinship carers by providing national information, resources and support to primary grandparent and kinship carers, and peer support groups;

a National Survey to better understand the demographics of non-parent carers and their needs to inform government policy and practices. The results of this survey will be available on the Australian Institution of Family Studies website in the near future; and
expansion of the existing Grandparent Advisers program.

The petitioners may find the Grandparent Adviser program useful in navigating the support options available for their situation. Grandparent Advisers are based in the Department of Human Services (DHS) and are trained to provide support, advice and assistance to grandparent carers to access Government payments and services. They also provide referrals to other community services providers dependent on individual cases. Grandparent Advisers can be contacted directly by contacting DHS on freecall 1800 245 956. More information on Grandparent Advisers can be found at www.humanservices.gov.au/customer/services/centrelink/grandparent-advisers.

The Australian Government Department of Social Services (DSS) also funds a range of services available to kinship carers in a formal or informal caring role. These include Children and Parenting Support Services which provide prevention and early intervention services, including peer support groups, playgroups and educational resources. Services are primarily targeted to children aged 0 to 12 years and are accessible to all parents and carers of children. Carers can use the search function at DSS Grants Service Directory www.serviceproviders.dss.gov.au/ to identify relevant services within their area.

DSS also funds the MyTime Peer Support Group Activity in select locations. MyTime groups provide facilitated free peer support for mothers, fathers, grandparents, kinship carers and anyone caring for a child with a disability or chronic medical condition or other complex needs. MyTime groups an opportunity for people living with similar experiences to support each other. Further information can be accessed at www.mytime.net.au, including locations and contacts for other peer support groups.

Furthermore, the Raising Children Network website, also funded by DSS, provides a complete resource for Australian parents, grandparents and kinship carers. It provides evidence-based information about raising children and caring for oneself as a parent or carer.
